text:
[? GEOFFREY JONES: ?]
It's clear you

feel passionate about a wider
responsibility for the region.
Can you talk a little bit--

FADI GHANDOUR: Yeah, absolutely,
I feel a wider-- look,

I feel extremely passionate
about the region.

And that goes back to my family
experience, to my father,

to the way we grew up,
to caring about society,

to feeling that we should have
a positive impact on society.

And then, when Aramex became the
organization that it is today,

I understood very well the
impact it has on society.

And then I started
thinking very much

as it stabilized-- even
though in the early days,
I thought about it.

But as Aramex
stabilized and became

profitable, and
powerful, and the brand,

and influential in
many ways, then I

understood the power
of the private sector.

I understood the power
of entrepreneurs.

And I understood the power
of how we affect society,
positively or negatively.

And because Aramex
was a positive story,

I understood how
positively it affected

youth, or entrepreneurs who
wanted to become entrepreneurs.

They took us as
their role model.

I wasn't building it
to become a role model.

I was building it to be
a stellar organization,

a beautiful organization that
hires fantastic people that
take it to places.

But then I suddenly realized
the fantastic attraction

it had on people and then
realized the impact on society.

And it became the issue of
whether business or businesses.

Only business-- you know, Milton
Friedman and him saying it's
only business.

While I adhere to
the concept, that no,

we have to be activists
for positive change,

specifically in volatile
societies, in emerging markets.

All emerging markets are
volatile one way or another,

politically, economically,
financially, civil wars, wars.

I don't have to explain to
you how the regions are.

So what does the
private sector do?

What does a
successful company do?

What does a capable
company do when

it lives in a society in
flux, or possibly in flux?

Do we go out and
say, you know, we

need to actually be active on
the ground to make sure that--

one, for selfish
reasons, I need stability
to build the business.

I'm not going to
just say I'm going

to benefit from somebody
else's influence on society
so that I can build my business.

And if it doesn't work,
I'll pack my bags and leave.
No, this is our hometown.

The youth that are
graduating from our colleges

are people that
we want to employ.

Their well-being is
from our well-being.

Society's well-being
is from our well-being.

And that's why you
see Aramex extremely
active over the years.

We changed the face of sports in
Jordan in the very early days.

We built and owned
a basketball club

that hired kids from the age
of five years old all the way

up to winning the national
championships in basketball--

completely nonprofit,
until today.

It's their 25th anniversary
today, the Aramex basketball
team.
It's called Al Riyadi.

It changed the
face of the game--
